Key Match Events: Yoshinobu Yamamoto outdueled Yu Darvish in a historic postseason matchup of Japanese-born starters
Kiké Hernández hit a solo home run in the second inning
Teoscar Hernández hit a home run in the seventh inning, chasing Darvish
Los Angeles Dodgers beat the San Diego Padres 2-0
The Padres' big hitters went scoreless for the final 24 innings of the series
The teams combined to retire 26 consecutive batters — the longest streak in a single game in postseason history
Pre-Game Insights: The Los Angeles Dodgers shelled out $1 billion for Japanese talent in the offseason and it’s paying off in the playoffs
Yu Darvish, who was Ohtani’s childhood idol, gave up an early home run to Kiké Hernández, then set down 14 in a row
Andrew Friedman, president of baseball operations, said the team successfully avoided a third straight NLDS elimination
The Padres’ big hitters went bust with their season on the line. Three-time batting champion Luis Arraez, Fernando Tatis Jr., Jurickson Profar and Manny Machado were 1 for 14 in Game 5
Yamamoto and Darvish were the first Japanese-born starting pitchers to square off in major league playoff history
Post-Match Reflections: Freddie Freeman said it was 'pretty sweet'
Mookie Betts said they went through a lot of injuries, a lot of ups and a lot of downs. We fight, we fight and keep going
Manager Dave Roberts said they’re ready for the next level and that they’d been in a little bit of a DS funk after getting down 2-1
Clayton Kershaw, Gavin Lux, Kopech, Walker Buehler and Tyler Glasnow huddled in a corner smoking victory cigars
Miscellaneous Highlights: The Padres became the first team to lead 2-1 in a best-of-five series and fail to push across a run in the final two games
The game was watched on Saturday morning in Japan
The Padres and Dodgers combined to score 43 runs in the first four games of the series, but the winner-take-all finale was a tense pitching affair
The game was played in front of a sellout crowd of 53,183 that included Los Angeles Lakers superstar LeBron James and a Hollywood contingent of Brad Pitt, Rob Lowe, Bryan Cranston and Jimmy Kimmel
